Authors: Schat, Anke; van Noorden, Martijn S.; van Amelsvoort, Therese; Giltay, Erik J.; van der Wee, Nic J. A.; Noom, Marc J.; Vermeiren, Robert R. J. M.; Zitman, Frans G.
Article Title: Age-related characteristics of outpatients with anxiety disorders: the Leiden routine outcome monitoring study
Abstract: Objective: It has been hypothesised that clinically important age-related differences between adults with anxiety disorders exist; this study aims to elucidate these differences.Methods: We analysed data from 1950 outpatients diagnosed with DSM-IV-TR anxiety disorders treated at a Dutch hospital or affiliated mental healthcare centres. Three age-groups (young- (18-25; n=435), mid- (26-40; n=788) and older adult (41-65; n=727)) were compared with regard to social demographic characteristics, diagnostic characteristics, anxiety symptom profile, general psychiatric symptom profile and generic health status, in addition, linear analyses were carried out with age as a continuous variable.Results: Average age was 36.48 years (SD 11.71), 62.8% were female. Significant associations with age emerged for gender, employment, education level, living situation, observed depression, agoraphobia (AP), social phobia, aches and pains, inner tension, sleep, interpersonal sensitivity, observed hostility, physical functioning, role limitations due to physical problems, vitality and bodily pain in categorical and continuous analyses. Self reported hostility was only significant in group-wise comparisons; role limitations due to emotional problems were only significant in linear analyses (all at p<.001).Conclusions: This study identified clinically relevant differences between younger and older adult outpatients with anxiety disorders. Clinicians should take these findings into account, as they may support treatment.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study does not directly address employment or labor outcomes, and instead focuses on social demographic characteristics, diagnostic characteristics, anxiety symptom profile, general psychiatric symptom profile, and generic health status.
llama-3.2-3b-instruct.study_design: Analytical study (categorical and continuous analyses) with no control group

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not address interventions related to employment policies and does not focus on outcomes such as employment rates, job duration, job quality, workplace integration, or job retention. It is a cross-sectional analysis of demographic and symptomological differences in outpatients with anxiety disorders.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study does not meet the inclusion criteria as it does not focus on employment interventions for people with mental health disorders, nor does it include job search services, adult training, wage subsidies, or supported employment as interventions.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: The study does not directly address employment interventions and does not present measures of employment or labor outcomes.
